introduction.p: A common way to increase the capacitance of a capacitor is to fill the space between the plates with a dielectric such as mica. With the reduced electric field between the plates the potential difference between the plates would be less. Therefore, you can put larger amount of charge on the plates for the same potential difference.

Let C_0 be the capacitance with nothing between the plates and C the capacitance, when the space is filled with a dielectric of dielectric constant \epsilon_r. The two will be related by
C = \epsilon_r C_0,
Usually mica, cardboard, or paper is put between the plates of a capacitor to increase the capacitance.

subsection.title: Capacitance of a Parallel Plate Capacitor with Dielectric
subsection.p:
Previously, we have worked out the formula for the electric field in a parallel plate capacitor of area A and separation d without a dielectric. We had found that, if the plates have charges \pm Q on them, then the magnitude of the electric field between plates is uniform with the magnitude given by
E_0 = \dfrac{Q/A}{\epsilon_0}, \ \ \ \text{(No dielectric.)}
Since this field is constant, multiplying this by the separation distance d gives the potential difference, which we will denote by \Delta \phi_0.
\Delta \phi_0 = \dfrac{Qd}{\epsilon_0 A}.
The ratio of charge Q to the voltage difference \Delta \phi_0 is the capacitance C_0 of the capacitor.
C_0 = \dfrac{\epsilon_0 A}{d}.
With a dielectric between the plates the magnitude of the electric field between the plates will be reduced by a factor of the dielectric constant, \epsilon_r.
E = \frac{E_0}{\epsilon_r}, \ \ \ \text{(with dielectric.)}
Therefore, potential difference \Delta \phi with dielectric between the plates will be less.
\Delta \phi = \dfrac{V_0}{\epsilon_r} = \dfrac{Qd}{\epsilon_r\epsilon_0 A}.
This gives the capacitance C for the capacitor with the dielectric in terms of the capacitance C_0 as
C = \frac{Q}{V} = \frac{\epsilon_r\epsilon_0 A}{d} = \epsilon_r C_0.
